fileContent.data:
## HISTORY

53-year-old Caucasian female presents to the Warren clinic with chief complaint of low back pain.  Patient states that she has been dealing with this pain for the past several weeks to months.  She states that it was excruciating 10 out of 10 low back pain with radiation of bilateral buttocks however no numbness tingling weakness in the bilateral lower extremities.  She even had a seek some injections and medications which provided only minimal relief now it is a 4 or 5 out of 10.  Patient states that her pain occurs a lot while she is sitting or when she is rising from sitting to standing and moving.

## PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hep B complicating pregnancy.

## MEDICATIONS

Motrin and vitamin D

## ALLERGIES

No known drug allergies

## PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

General: Awake alert oriented, no acute distress.
HEENT: Normocephalic atraumatic extract muscles intact
Pulmonary: No EXTR
Abdomen: Obese female with a BMI of 45.
Neurological: 5-5 strength throughout, sensation intact light touch throughout, negative Hoffmann's bilaterally, reflexes 2 out of 4 throughout, negative straight leg raise bilaterally.  Normal gait.
MSK: Nontender palpation of cervical thoracic or lumbar spine or bilateral PSIS.

## IMAGING

MRI of the lumbar spine shows disc herniations at L3-L4 L4-L5 and L5-S1.  X-rays of the lumbar spine show no evidence of scoliosis however there is disc collapse particularly at L3-L4 and L4-L5.  There is evidence of spondylolisthesis at L3-L4.

## IMPRESSIONS

53-year-old Caucasian female presents to the Warren clinic with chief complaint of low back pain.  I believe there is a component of discogenic and mechanical back pain involved with disc herniations at L3-L4 with spondylolisthesis at this level, L4-L5 and L5-S1.

## PLAN

1.  I discussed with this patient weight loss.
2.  Physical therapy
3.  Pain management referral
4.  Pain medication with meloxicam she was explained it is a stronger version ibuprofen and is to be taken instead of her current ibuprofen.
5.  Referral to Dr. Hares for abdominal access for anterior lumbar interbody fusion.
6.  I discussed with the patient that if she feels conservative management she would be a candidate for anterior lumbar interbody fusion with posterior instrumentation and fusion from L3-S1.
7.  Follow-up in 2 weeks, patient states that she will be in Romania for the next 3 or so weeks and will follow-up in approximately 3 to 4 weeks.
